Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Manhattan College Engineering Scholarship Initiative will provide scholarships to a total of twelve (six in each of two cohorts) academically qualified and financially needy students to pursue accredited four-year undergraduate degree programs in Civil and Mechanical Engineering. Nationwide, there is a need to increase the numbers of students in the field of engineering especially from women and minority groups. Manhattan College recognizes this need and is committed to helping diversify the engineering workforce and produce opportunities for students with financial needs. The students will be selected from existing summer outreach programs at Manhattan College. These programs, some running continuously for over 30 years, specifically encourage high school students who are either female and/or considered underrepresented minorities and most of whom reside in low-income neighborhoods and qualify for financial aid. The selection process will ensure that the program will attract qualified women and underrepresented minority students with documented financial needs.

The students will be selected to meet academic eligibility criteria and support activities and programs will be instituted to ensure student retention and success. The support system will include preparatory and annual workshops, living-learning communities, and mentorship (peer, professional, and academic). The proposed project will interact with the ACE (Architecture, Construction, and Engineering) Mentorship Program, where the scholarship students will have the opportunity to serve as junior mentors to high school students, while they themselves concurrently receive professional mentorship from industry leaders. Optional activities, such as study-abroad program and undergraduate research, will enrich the students' college experience and inspire them to consider pursuing graduate degrees, in addition to careers in engineering industry. A strong external-evaluation program will inquire into the effects of individual co-curricular and extra-curricular activities on student retention and eventual success of each student, by comparing scholarship students with a comparable general student population. The benefits and challenges of each activity will be enumerated, along with resources required in each case. The results of this part of the study will help educators and administrators identify activities where they may utilize their resources most efficiently.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project outcomes Report

Manhattan College Engineering Scholarship Initiative (MCESI) program awarded $480,000 scholarship to 15 students in two cohorts over five years.  The program recruited students using several existing pre-college programs at Manhattan College offered to women and underrepresented minorities in engineering. That resulted in recruiting more than 53% of these students being women and/or underrepresented minorities in engineering.

From their first day at the college, they received peer and faculty mentoring, which proved to be the most important and effective support that they received during their quest toward a successful engineering education and career. They also received one on one and group tutoring specially during the first two years that they were taking fundamental courses.

In addition, to make sure they have all the required tools to be successful, several different professional development trainings were offered. In year 1, students had information sessions to learn about available resources around the campus and started preparing their resumes and participating in career fair. Year 2, they have received several workshops on technical writing, effective presentations, engineering ethics, etc. Year 3, some participated in undergraduate research, some attended study abroad programs, some interned in industry and some participated in ACE mentor program where they mentored high school students while they were mentored by practicing engineers. Year 4, they participated in training on how to apply for internship and jobs and prepare themselves for job interview. 

The students who joined this program from all different backgrounds, were all graduated by May 2020. Only one out of 15 students switched major to a non-STEM major (accounting). 100% of the graduated students in engineering field are either working in engineering related fields or started graduate school and pursuing higher education in STEM fields. The overall average GPA for this group of students is 3.58.

The program also recruited other students who were eligible to participate but because of limited funding did not received the scholarship. However, these students benefited from the entire support services offered and helped to build a community of learners.  

In 2020 when all the educational programs moved to online format because of the global pandemic, we developed online resources (videos and documents) on professional development such as "networking", "negotiating", "professionalism" ant etc. where provided students with the help that they needed to get ready for getting a job and being successful.
